awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Do arc-continent collisions in the tropics set the Earth's climate state?
awd_abstract_narration:
Over its history, Earth has experienced warm ice-free and cold glacial climates, but it is unknown if transitions between these background climate states were the result of changes in CO2 sources or sinks. On these multi-million year geological timescales, CO2 enters the ocean and atmosphere primarily by volcanic outgassing and is removed primarily though the chemical erosion of rocks, which delivers calcium and magnesium via rivers to the ocean where they react with CO2 to form carbonate. It is hypothesized that the tectonic closure of ocean basins and formation of mountains at equatorial latitudes could drive cooling by creating topography and eroding highly soluble oceanic rocks in the warm, wet tropics. This process increases global weatherability, thereby increasing Earth's potential to sequester CO2 in carbonates through chemical erosion. The investigators aim to test the hypothesis that changes in global weatherability have controlled the Earth's background climate state with coupled geological, geochemical, and modelling studies. This broader impact of this work will benefit society by generating and disseminating knowledge about geological climate change at both the K-12 and college level. 

The researchers have developed a global database of arc-continent collisions through the Phanerozoic, which mark the closure of former ocean basins, and reconstructed their position with state-of-the-art paleogeographic models. The results from this analysis revealed a temporal coincidence between the maximum global extent of arc-continent collision in the tropics and the occurrence of every major glacial period in the Phanerozoic. The investigators will refine geological constraints and tectonic reconstructions in five critical belts. Through these case studies, the researchers will generate thermochronological data and refine the exhumation history of New Guinea and construct a new paleogeographic model for suturing in the Alpine-Himalaya belt. The investigators will also acquire new stratigraphic, geochronological, geological, petrographic, geochemical, and paleomagnetic data along Permo-Carboniferous sutures from Mexico to South America, Ordovician sutures in the northern Appalachian, and Neoproterozoic sutures in the Arabian-Nubian Shield. These field and laboratory data will be integrated with paleogeographic, weathering, and climate models to develop estimates for the change in pCO2 resulting from arc-continent collisions in the tropics utilizing the GEOCLIM model framework. This framework integrates climate models run at varying pCO2 with global weathering models such that the variable climatology can be used to estimate the effect of changes in global weatherability model on long-term steady-state pCO2 levels. In this framework, the investigators will perform sensitivity tests to isolate the effects of specific parameters such as lithology or topography. The researchers will further calibrate these models with source-to-sink cation studies in modern and paleo ophiolite watersheds. Finally, they will develop statistical methods to evaluate the strength of correlation and test hypothesized causal mechanisms for environmental change. Through this research the investigators will directly train a postdoctoral researcher, 5 PhD students and numerous undergraduate research assistants. To disseminate this basic research, the team will hold public seminars and workshops with K-12 teachers, and construct classes on Tectonics and Climate with online course materials, both at the high-school and undergraduate level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Earth’s climate has fluctuated between warm, ice-free conditions and cold, glacial periods over millions of years. This project explored how low-latitude arc-continent collisions influence climate by enhancing carbon sequestration through the chemical weathering rocks in the warm, wet tropics. We aimed to test this hypothesis through a combination of field studies, laboratory analyses, climate modeling, and statistical approaches, focusing on two critical periods in Earth’s history: the Neogene (23 million years ago up until the onset of northern hemisphere glaciation at 2.5 million years ago) and the Neoproterozoic (during which time there was global Snowball Earth glaciation).

Research on the Neogene focused on the Southeast Asian islands given that they are a modern-day hotspot of CO2 consumption via silicate weathering. Since 15 million years ago, these islands have been increasing in size and height while Earth’s climate has been cooling.  Previous research had highlighted how additional land area enhances convective rainfall, facilitating both increased silicate weathering and the development of the modern-day Walker circulation. Using an Earth system modeling approach, project research found instead that increasing topography (as opposed to land area) in the Southeast Asian islands is central to both effects. As part of the research effort, we compiled paleoshoreline data that were used as inputs to the coupled silicate weathering and climate model GEOCLIM. We found that this emergence is associated with a large decrease in pCO2 and temperature. Without these changes in tropical island paleogeography, there would not have been large Northern Hemisphere ice sheets as a defining feature of Earth’s climate over the past 3 million years. These results support a significant role for the progressive emergence of SEAI topography in global cooling in the Neogene.

In the Neoproterozoic, similar arc terranes to those in the modern-day Southeast Asian islands developed and collided in a region now known as the Arabian-Nubian Shield. Inspired by project data on the Southeast Asian Islands, we formulated the hypothesis that Arabian Nubian arc terranes could have played a pivotal role in cooling Earth's climate leading up to the onset of Cryogenian Snowball Earth. New data developed through project research from the northern margin of the ancient ocean in which the arcs developed is consistent with this hypothesis that links tropical arc collisions to climate cooling that set the stage for Snowball Earth glaciations.

The project advanced knowledge, education, and infrastructure development. The GEOCLIM Earth System Model was released as open-source software for the first time enabling researchers to apply it to study the long-term evolution of Earth’s climate coupled to silicate weathering. The project trained undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral researchers, providing them with hands-on experience in fieldwork, laboratory analyses, and computational modeling. Participants have advanced to impactful roles in academia and industry. Project results were shared with California high school students through lessons on the carbon cycle and climate dynamics, inspiring the next generation of Earth scientists.

Overall, the project demonstrated that tectonic processes, such as the rise of the Southeast Asia Islands are critical drivers of Earth’s long-term climate by enhancing the efficiency of silicate weathering and associated carbon sequestration. Project research has resulted in 22 products that have been contributed to the NSF Public Access Repository associated with advancing understanding of the drivers of Earth’s long-term climate.
